text:
It's so great to see
everyone here today--

Dean Datar, Mr. Raymond
McGuire, distinguished

guests, family, friends, and,
of course, the class of 2023.
[APPLAUSE]

My name is Sam Deutsch, and I'm
a proud member of Section C.
[APPLAUSE]

And I'm also the Harvard
Business School Student

Association's Head Senator
for the class of 2023.

We would like to also
recognize and thank

our faculty leadership who have
joined us on the stage today.

When I call your
name, please stand.

Matt Weinzierl,
MBA program chair.
[APPLAUSE]

Mitch Weiss, required
curriculum chair.
[APPLAUSE]

Kristin Mugford, co
curriculum and field chair.
[APPLAUSE]

VG Narayanan, elective
curriculum chair.
[APPLAUSE]

And Jan Rivkin, the
past MBA program chair.
[APPLAUSE]

Before we begin
today's proceedings,

we want to make two
acknowledgments.

First, we acknowledge
that Harvard University

is situated upon the traditional
land of the Massachusett tribe.

We acknowledge the painful
history of genocide

and forced removal
from this territory,

and we honor and respect the
many diverse Indigenous people
still connected to this land.

May we work together
to restore this land.

Second, between 1636 and
1783, more than 70 individuals

were enslaved by Harvard
leaders, faculty, and staff.

May we honor their
memory and the memory

of all the enslaved
women, men, and children

whose labor generated
the wealth that helped

create the Harvard
we know today.

Last year, the
university released

the, "Harvard and the
Legacy of Slavery"

report that I strongly recommend
reading to further understand
this difficult subject.

These acknowledgments
are intended

to stand alongside our
celebrations this week

and to recognize the ongoing
efforts by the university

and its affiliates to
consider their history

and the present day
implications of that history.

To our guests, we thank you
for joining the class of 2023
and reflecting on this legacy.

We also want to thank
you for joining us

as we conclude our time here
at Harvard Business School.

Tomorrow, we will join all
of Harvard University and Tom
Hanks for commencement.
But today is special for HBS.

We've had a seriously
tumultuous two years here.

We've had to deal with a
changing economy, a changing

pandemic, and a world that
feels more uncertain than ever.

In many ways, the class
of 2023 was a bridge.

We started our HBS experience
with masking and almost

daily COVID tests, and
we ended with a return

to some sense of
normalcy in the classroom
after three years of a pandemic.

It's been difficult at times,
especially when a COVID

breakout ended up in
the Wall Street Journal.

But it's also been
an opportunity

to craft new traditions and
reflect on the role of business

and what all of us can
do to tackle the greatest

challenges of our time, from
LGBTQ rights, to health care,

to racial justice,
to climate change.

And by the way, props to
everyone who took the T here.

HBS' mission is to, quote,
"educate leaders who make
a difference in the world."

But I actually think
that's inadequate.

We need to be leaders
making a positive difference
in the world.

Business does not
operate in a vacuum.

And we cannot ignore
these pressing issues.

But as I look around
at my fellow graduates,

I am hopeful, because I have
had the privilege of spending

the past two years
with a uniquely

thoughtful, passionate, and,
perhaps most importantly,
compassionate group of people.

I'd like to think that
it is classes like ours

that the class of 1996
was thinking about when
they dreamed up class day.

So 27 years after
its inception, let's

remember the original
intent of class day

and allow ourselves time
to formally reflect on

and celebrate our
unique HBS experience.
